Reviewing the Security Event Log

You can view the application security event log at any time, provided that you have access rights to the server configuration. It is not a typical .log file, as its data is stored in the application database and cannot be accessed from the Server Administration tool.

The log lists each secured event (such as logging on or off and creating items), the date and time it occurred, the ID of the user performing the operation, the IP address of the workstation from which the operation was initiated, the item acted upon, and whether the operation failed.

Note: You can perform this function only on servers that are currently running.

To view the security event log:

  1. Do one of the following:

    • On a computer that has the Server installed, select Start > Programs > StarTeam > StarTeam Server x.x > StarTeam Server.

    • From the client, select Start > Programs > StarTeam > StarTeam client_name > Server Administration (available with custom installations only).

    These actions display the Server Administration dialog.

  2. Select a server configuration from the left pane.  If you have not yet logged onto the server configuration, you will be asked to do so. If you are using the client, you can access remote server configurations only.

  3. From the Server Administration dialog, do one of the following:

    • Click the Accounts bar in the lower left panel. Then click the Security Log shortcut.

    • From the menu, select Tools > Accounts > User Manager.

    The Security Log dialog opens.  

  4. Select an event of interest from the Security event type drop-down list box to see all events of that type.

  5. To print the data, select it and click the Print Selection button.

  6. To reload the security event log and review the most recent entries, click Reload.

  7. Click OK to exit the dialog.

Event Types

The following types of events are included in the Security Event Log:

Acquire item ownership

Ownership is not implemented at this time.

Add item owner

At this time, indicates that a user created a folder or an item.

Add user/group

Indicates that a user or group was added to the server configuration.

Add/Edit container access rights

Indicates that access rights were added or changed for a group of objects contained in another object. For example, if you select Project > Access Rights and change access rights for all change requests in the project, that event fits in this category.

Add/Edit item access rights

Indicates that access rights were added or changed for a specific object. For example, if you change project access rights, that event shows up under this heading. If you change the access rights for a specific change request, that event fits in this category.

Delete container access rights

Indicates that access rights were deleted at the container level.

Delete item access rights

Indicates that access rights were deleted at the item level.

Delete item owner

Ownership is not implemented at this time.

Delete user/group

Indicates that a user or group was deleted.

Edit user/group

Indicates that the properties for user or group were changed in some way.

Force user logoff

Indicates that a user was forced to log off the server configuration.

Logon

Indicates that a user logged onto the server configuration.

Logon attempt: Suspended account

Indicates that a user attempted to log on, and the account was suspended.

Logon attempt: Account lockout

Indicates that a user attempted to log on, and the account was locked.

Logon attempt: Expired password

Indicates that a user attempted to log on, and the password had expired.

Logon attempt: No such logon name

Indicates that a user attempted to log on with a non-existent user name.

Logon attempt: Restricted access time

Indicates that a user attempted to log on at a time when he or she was not allowed access.

Logon failure

Indicates that an incorrect password was used during the log on process.

Logoff

Indicates that a user logged off the server configuration.

Item access check

Indicates that access rights were checked to see if the user could access a specific item.

Policy change

Indicates that a system policy has changed.

User status change

Indicates that an administrator suspended, reactivated, locked, unlocked or required a password change on a user's account.
